title: Australian equity capital markets activity returns to 2009 levels
text:
Large equity raisings by the likes of the Commonwealth Bank and others have buoyed local ECM numbers. by Joyce Moullakis Bankers and lawyers expect a steady rather than a stellar finish to 2015 for local equity capital markets volumes, even as new share issues for the finance sector surged to record year-to-date levels underpinned by bumper Australian bank raisings.
Total Australian equity capital markets (ECM) activity amounts to $US29.9 billion ($41.6 billion) so far this year, up 22.4 per cent on the same time in 2014, and the highest year-to-date level since 2009, according to Dealogic data. The numbers include equity raisings, initial public offerings and convertible issuance.
Large equity raisings by the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, ANZ Banking Group and National Australia Bank have buoyed this year's numbers, as banks have moved to bolster their capital buffers.
Finance sector ECM volume has climbed to a record $US12.1 billion so far this year.
Secondary issuance has been the standout this year, Dealogic data showed, as new issuance reflecting sharemarket floats dropped 53 per cent over the period to $US3.2 billion. The largest initial public offering in the September quarter was the float of fresh food business Costa Group.
The runway for IPOs is bumpy, however, following the postponement, cancellation and repricing of various offers this year. An institutional bookbuild for the Aventus Retail Property Fund listing was delayed last week and the float of insurance distributor Greenstone was also shelved earlier this year as fund managers questioned pricing around the transaction.
Some companies are not deterred by the environment and are still lining up for a run at the local bourse despite shaky market conditions. Among those are private-equity-backed Link Group, healthcare company Integral Diagnostics and retailer Baby Bunting.
Block trades have also been a feature of activity this year as many stakes in companies that listed last year, or earlier, come out of escrow. Among recent sell-downs are stakes in hospital company Healthscope and hotel group Mantra.
 Morgan Stanley's local investment banking chief Richard Wagner expects a measured finish to 2015 for local ECM, barring any major ructions in markets offshore.
"From where we sit today we are going to see the ECM backlog clear out," he said.
Herbert Smith Freehills' partner Philippa Stone also expects a steady finish to the year for ECM activity, including more block trades, against the backdrop of continued volatility in markets and concerns around domestic economic growth.
"We are aware of significant and continuing IPO interest," she said. "Obviously one is cautious, particularly as markets are choppy ... but we are cautiously optimistic."
Macquarie Group's co-head of ECM, Hugh Falcon, said: "There are four or five quality IPOs for the remainder of the year and we expect they will be well received by the market, notwithstanding the recent spike in volatility.
"Block trades have been a significant feature this year," Mr Falcon added, noting that many of the transactions had been executed at "tighter discounts" in 2015 than in previous years.
Mr Falcon also said that while the anticipated increase in M&A financing had not materialised in a big way, activity via balance sheet repair had risen.
In the ECM league tables for Australia, UBS ranks in top spot with transactions amounting to $US6.4 billion. Goldman Sachs and Macquarie rank second and third.
Mergers and acquisitions (M&A) activity has been strong so far this year, but has lagged frenzied global activity. Australia targeted M&A volume totals $US79.1 billion in 2015, up 31 per cent on the same period last year and the highest year-to-date total since 2011. Those figures do not include outbound transactions by Australian companies, which have almost doubled to $US19.3 billion.
Woodside Petroleum's $11 billion-plus bid for Oil Search is the largest deal announced in 2015 so far, despite some doubts about whether a transaction will be consummated.
Dealogic noted that the transport sector was the busiest for M&A this year, helped by Brookfield Infrastructure Partners' tilt at Asciano. The mining and oil-and-gas sectors were the next-busiest industry groupings for deals.
Mr Wagner is of the view that with the lower Australian currency stabilising at current levels more inbound acquisitions may be on the horizon.
In the M&A tables, Macquarie leads the pack working on transactions amounting to $US34.4 billion. Gresham Partners and Goldman Sachs round out the top three.
In debt capital markets, Australian year-to-date bond issuance fell to $US109.4 billion, reflecting a four-year low for volumes as at September 16. NAB led the DCM tables.
Macquarie was out in front on Dealogic's core investment banking fee measure, followed by UBS and JPMorgan.
